questions.text: With tracheal tubes, all are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: Cuff pressure should be kept less than 25 mm hg.

options.label: B
options.text: low-pressure high-volume cuffs provide better protection against aspiration.

options.label: C
options.text: Nitrous oxide can cause the cuff pressure to increase.

options.label: D
options.text: Bevelling of the tip of the ETT provides better visualization of vocal cords during intubation.

questions.correct_answer: B. low-pressure high-volume cuffs provide better protection against aspiration.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female undergoes an uneventful exploratory laparotomy. Chest and abdominal x-rays are performed to evaluate for a lost sponge in the counts at the end of the case. The chest x-ray incidentally reveals that the endotracheal tube is sitting just at the carina. One of the trainee surgeons becomes worried and asks for the tube to be adjusted. However, the anesthetist does not show concern. Which of the following best explains why the anesthetist is unconcerned?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the end of the case and even if one lung isn’t ventilated it won’t have any clinical significance.

options.label: B
options.text: Placement of the endotracheal tube at the level of the carina is optimal.

options.label: C
options.text: Both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray; this is likely because the lungs are being ventilated via the Murphy eye of the endotracheal tube.

options.label: D
options.text: Both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray; this is likely because the positive pressure ventilation is blowing the carina away from the endotracheal tube and allowing both lungs to be ventilated.

questions.correct_answer: C. Both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray; this is likely because the lungs are being ventilated via the Murphy eye of the endotracheal tube.

questions.text: A 54-year-old professional singer presents to the hospital with a ruptured appendix. He is scheduled for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. He is very worried about endotracheal intubation because of his profession. He requests the use of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) and does not want to be intubated. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: A larger sized LMA than usual

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of obesity is undergoing an elective herniorrhaphy. Anesthesia is successfully induced. Right after giving a muscle relaxant, positive pressure ventilation by face mask fails to provide an adequate seal. His oxygen saturation of the patient begins to fall. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask for a large plastic adhesive, cut a hole into it and place over the patient's mouth to make a seal.

options.label: B
options.text: Rush to tracheostomy as mask ventilation is failing.

options.label: C
options.text: Attempt to find a larger mask to make a better seal.

options.label: D
options.text: Place a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.correct_answer: D. Place a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is scheduled for an appendectomy. The patient is administered glycopyrrolate along with other routine drugs just before intubating the patient. Which of the following side effects is expected postoperatively?

A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic for pre-operative evaluation for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient says he is feeling well, remembers many years ago, was diagnosed with some joint condition, and was advised to take mediations for which he would have to do blood tests regularly. He was not interested in doing the regular blood tests and seeing a clinician regularly, hence he never took treatment for the disease. On examination has bilateral ulnar deviation and subluxation of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Hand X-ray shows erosions of MCP and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP antibodies are positive. The patient also complaints of stiffness in his neck. Which of the following is the next best step in the pre operative evaluation of this patient?

A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease presents for open reduction and internal fixation of the right humerus fracture following a fall. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/78 mmHg, a heart rate of 85/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Laboratory values are noted for hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, sodium of 147 mEq/L, potassium of 5.6 mEq/L, urea of 43 mg/dL, and a creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL. Serum glucose is 242 mg/dL. Using the revised cardiac risk index, what is this patient's risk of perioperative major adverse cardiovascular events?

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot comment on the level of risk

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with COPD, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism presents to the emergency department with cough and shortness of breath. The patient is found to have acute on chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure. His pH on arterial blood gas is 7.1, pCO2 90 mmHg, and pO2 100 mmHg on a nonrebreather mask. Upon evaluating his mouth, the clinician is unable to pass more than two fingers between upper and lower teeth. Because of the possibility of a difficult airway, the patient is intubated with a video laryngoscope after giving intravenous etomidate and rocuronium. The patient is now transferred to ICU. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Keep the patient paralyzed after intubation so he cannot self-extubate himself.

options.label: B
options.text: Plan tracheostomy as the patient has a difficult airway.

options.label: C
options.text: Place "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid suctioning the patient as it will traumatize the tissue and it will lead to airway oedema.

questions.correct_answer: C. Place "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is admitted for elective left-sided lobectomy of upper lobe for lung nodule with suspicion of malignancy. She was diagnosed with a 1.2 cm pulmonary nodule 3 months ago. On repeat CT chest, the size of the nodule increased to 3 cm. During anesthesia, what is the best device for intraoperative ventilation of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Regular endotracheal tube and a bronchial blocker

questions.text: Comment on the difficulty of intubation by looking at the following image?

A 40-year-old chronic smoker was scheduled for cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. He was induced with propofol and vecuronium and started on isoflurane for maintenance of anesthesia. During the procedure, the following capnograph plot was observed. What is the possible cause?

options.label: B
options.text: Entry into the right sided bronchus

questions.correct_answer: B. Entry into the right sided bronchus

questions.text: Which of the following would result in the greatest decrease in the arterial haemoglobin saturation (Spo2) value measured by the dual-wavelength pulse oximeter?
questions.correct_answer: C. Intravenous injection of methylene blue

questions.text: Regarding pulse oximeters:

options.label: A
options.text: They are reliable even in the situation of shock.

options.label: B
options.text: They tend to give falsely low readings in patients with carbon monoxide toxicity.

options.label: C
options.text: They are useful as they provide an indication of the adequacy of a patient’s minute ventilation.

options.label: D
options.text: Higher number on the reading indicates a predominantly oxygenated blood.

questions.correct_answer: D. Higher number on the reading indicates a predominantly oxygenated blood.

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to experience intraoperative awareness under anesthesia except?

options.label: B
options.text: An adult patient under muscle relaxation.

options.label: C
options.text: A patient with a bispectral index monitor

options.label: D
options.text: An American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA)physical status V patient

questions.correct_answer: C. A patient with a bispectral index monitor

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly starts showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anaesthesiologist?

options.label: A
options.text: The anesthesiologist immediately changed the endotracheal tube with a larger tube

options.label: B
options.text: The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol

options.label: C
options.text: The anesthesiologist changed the ventilator settings to higher tidal volume

options.label: D
options.text: The anesthesiologist informed the surgeon to stop the surgery

questions.correct_answer: B. The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the ICU after elective repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His vital signs are stable, but he requires a sodium nitroprusside infusion at a rate of 10 μg/kg/min to keep the systolic blood pressure below 110 mm Hg. The Sao2 is 98% with controlled ventilation at 12 breaths/min and an Fio2 of 0.60. After 3 days, his Sao2 decreases to 85% on the pulse oximeter. Chest x-ray film and results of physical examination are unchanged. Which of the following would most likely account for this desaturation?

A 72 old patient is in intensive care following his coronary artery bypass grafting surgery 3 days back. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation as his vitals are down and his ejection fraction has been keeping low. He is on an infusion of noradrenaline and dobutamine to keep his blood pressure normal and there is significant deterioration of his condition in the past 12 hours. Suddenly in the middle of the noon, this patient experienced a sudden cardiac arrest and the code blue team was paged and CPR was immediately started. The patient had an arterial line in place and a continuous capnography was also used to monitor the patient. Which of the following uses of capnography in this situation is justified except?

options.label: A
options.text: Monitoring the effectiveness of ongoing CPR

options.label: C
options.text: Monitoring the metabolic acidosis due to cardiac arrest

questions.correct_answer: C. Monitoring the metabolic acidosis due to cardiac arrest

questions.text: A 23-year-old female is taken up for a short procedure of dilatation and evacuation of her uterus due to an incomplete abortion. The patient has no past medical history and has never been operative before. A standard general anesthesia is planned with induction with propofol and fentanyl and scoline as a short acting muscle relaxant and a laryngeal mask airway for ventilation. Due to some unexpected bleeding the surgeon took longer than normal for the procedure and the anesthesiologist gave multiple doses of scoline to keep the patient from breathing spontaneously. After the procedure, the patient remained apnoeic for almost 2 hours with no signs of neuromuscular activity, but consciousness was achieved. To identify the cause the anesthesiologist did a neuromuscular monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator and found the response on train of four stimulation as shown in image A. which of the following statements about the diagnosis and management of this condition is true? Image A

options.label: A
options.text: Atypical pseudocholinesterase leading to prolonged apnea and need to give neostigmine to reverse it

options.label: B
options.text: Undiagnosed liver dysfunction leading to pseudocholinesterase deficiency and replacement by administration of fresh frozen plasma

options.label: C
options.text: Hypothermia leading to prolongation of action of scoline and so warming will resume the neuromuscular function

options.label: D
options.text: Phase II blockade due to excessive dose of scoline and continuing mechanical ventilation and sedation the patient.

questions.correct_answer: D. Phase II blockade due to excessive dose of scoline and continuing mechanical ventilation and sedation the patient.

questions.text: Capnography (end-tidal co2 monitoring) can help diagnose the following except
Regarding the bispectral index (BIS):

options.label: A
options.text: It can distinguish between causes of decreased brain activity.

options.label: C
options.text: It predicts movement to surgical stimulus.

options.label: D
options.text: Higher values represent more cortical activity.

questions.correct_answer: D. Higher values represent more cortical activity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ketamine are true?

options.label: B
options.text: It antagonizes the excitatory neurotransmitter glycine at NMDA receptors.

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases cerebral metabolic oxygen requirement.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative.

questions.text: Concerning etomidate:

options.label: B
options.text: Hypnosis occurs through action on the NMDA receptor.

options.label: C
options.text: Etomidate can lead to pain during injection.

questions.correct_answer: C. Etomidate can lead to pain during injection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy. The child gives a history of cyanotic spells from childhood. The mother says that her child has a heart condition. Which of the following would be a preferred drug for induction of this patient?
Which of the following induction agents can be used safely in long term infusion except?
All the following anaesthetic agents can cause seizure like activity on EEG except:

A 17-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after getting shot in the eye by a BB gun. On initial assessment, the patient has a subconjunctival hemorrhage of the left eye with deformity of the globe. The patient's vision in that eye is 20/400 at three feet. The clinician uses a fluorescein strip and finds the patient to be Seidel positive at the limbus, extending back into the sclera at the two o'clock position. The clinician decides that the patient needs urgent surgical intervention. Given this patient's clinical presentation, what anesthetic would be preferred in this patient?

A patient is experiencing a symptomatic new wide complex QRS rhythm that is unstable. Cardioversion is indicated. He has a high ASA risk score (unstable uncontrolled ischemic heart disease and diabetes) with a Mallampati score of 2. What is the most appropriate sedative agent for this patient?

A 55-year-old female was admitted to the ICU due to Guillain-Barre syndrome. Over the last 3 days, she had been showing signs of improvement but required continued propofol sedation and intubation for ventilatory support as well as parenteral nutrition. On her 4th day of admission, she began to show an acute decline in cardiac function. Her labs revealed lactic acidosis, elevated creatine kinase, and hyperkalemia. Which of the following contributed to her worsening status in the ICU?

A 65-year-old male suffering from chronic shoulder pain is undergoing inguinal hernia repair. During the case, the patients' mean arterial pressure is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain above a goal of 65 mmHg. There is no significant blood loss. ETCO2 monitor reads a normal output of 35 mmHg, which has been stable throughout the case. The blood pressure cuff is securely in place. The patients' home medications include over the counter paracetamol, and oral steroid daily. What is the most likely cause of these patients' hemodynamic instability?
Drugs safe to use in porphyria include all except:
Concerning Suxamethonium all are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is formed by combining two acetylcholine molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a trigger for malignant hyperpyrexia.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with myasthenia gravis are likely to require a reduced dose of Suxamethonium.

questions.correct_answer: D. Patients with myasthenia gravis are likely to require a reduced dose of Suxamethonium.

questions.text: Atracurium:

options.label: A
options.text: Is a short acting muscle relaxant.

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle relaxation may be reversed by the administration of sugammadex.

questions.text: Cisatracurium all are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: Is derived from pure cis isomer of atracurium.

options.label: B
options.text: Produces less histamine release compared to atracurium.

options.label: C
options.text: Is eliminated predominantly via Hoffman degradation.

options.label: D
options.text: May be preferred over atracurium in asthmatic patients as it is not metabolized to laudanosine

questions.correct_answer: D. May be preferred over atracurium in asthmatic patients as it is not metabolized to laudanosine

questions.text: Which of the following drug should be preferred for rsi in a patient with serum potassium of 5.5 meq\l?
which of the following muscle relaxants will be preferred in a neonate?

A 45-year-old woman is being taken to the operating room for same-day surgery, after which she is scheduled to return home. She has no acute complaints. Her past medical history is limited but includes a tonsillectomy 40 years ago with no complications or issues with anesthesia at that time. Her family history is significant for hypertension and diabetes. She drinks alcohol only in social sittings approximately once a week and has never smoked. She has history of asthma. Preoperative vital signs show heart rate 59/minute, blood pressure 128\64 mmHg and temperature 37 C. Physical exam reveals a generally well-appearing healthy 45-year-old female with a Mallampati score of 2 and a full range of motion in her neck. She is given a standard induction with propofol and atracurium as muscle relaxant. What effect is most likely to be seen during induction based on her preoperative course and evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased time to onset and duration of action of atracurium

options.label: B
options.text: Increased time to onset of atracurium

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden bradycardia and hypotension and urticaria.

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden difficulty in ventilation and hypotension and flushing of skin.

questions.correct_answer: D. Sudden difficulty in ventilation and hypotension and flushing of skin.

questions.text: A 57-year-old white male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset diffuse abdominal, sharp stabbing in nature, and radiating directly to the back. His past medical history is only significant for diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidaemia, and hypertension. He has never had a surgical procedure previously and denies a family history of reactions to anesthesia. Electrolytes, urine drug screen, clotting function, and complete blood count are within normal limits except for haemoglobin of 7.9 grams/dL. Due to unstable vital signs, the patient is brought directly to the operating room from the emergency department, for an exploratory laparotomy secondary to a gunshot wound to the abdomen. Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) medications are pushed prior to securing an airway. The patient is paralyzed for 40 mins despite only receiving the single bolus of paralytic medication. What is the best explanation for this prolonged effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Paralytic agent used must be rocuronium

options.label: B
options.text: This is an expected duration of action for the medication used

options.label: C
options.text: The patient has an upregulation of plasma cholinesterase secondary to an extensive history of cocaine abuse

options.label: D
options.text: Severe Butyryl cholinesterase deficiency resulted in a significantly decreased clearance of succinylcholine

questions.correct_answer: D. Severe Butyryl cholinesterase deficiency resulted in a significantly decreased clearance of succinylcholine

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman was undergoing surgery to remove a breast cancer. The anesthesia was induced by thiopental, maintained by isoflurane and supplemented with a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker which has a short duration of action and is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?

A 44-year-old man, brought to the emergency room after a car accident, required intubation and mechanical ventilation. Patient history was significant for a genetically deficient plasma cholinesterase. A muscle relaxant was administered IV. Which of the following muscle relaxants would be contraindicated in this patient?
Rocuronium:

options.label: A
options.text: Is predominantly excreted by hoffman’s elimination.

options.label: B
options.text: Can raise arterial blood pressure and heart rate

options.label: D
options.text: Will usually provide intubating conditions within 30 s

questions.correct_answer: B. Can raise arterial blood pressure and heart rate

questions.text: Advantages of the Mapleson systems include all of the following except

options.label: A
options.text: No production of toxic waste products.

questions.correct_answer: C. Useful in treating malignant hyperthermia.

questions.text: Preferred anaesthetic agent in a patient with hyperthyroidism included?
Which of the following inhaled anesthetic agents has highest risk of development of carbon monoxide in a closed circuit?

A 19-year-old female presents to the preoperative suite for her elective breast augmentation surgery. In the interview, she denies any knowledge of medical conditions. She has never had surgery before. She is unaware of any family members who have had issues with general anesthesia. She is on no medications and denies any tobacco and alcohol usage. All her preoperative testing is within normal limits. She consented to general anesthesia. Two hours into her operation, she starts to seize. Which of the following most likely caused her to seize?

A 75-year-old man American association anaesthesiology class-III (ASA-III) with a history of coronary artery disease, chronic renal disease, and obstructive sleep apnea is taken to the operating room for inguinal hernia repair. He had been seen by a cardiologist and cleared for surgery. General anesthesia via LMA is considered with maintenance using desflurane. Vital signs are normal prior to pre-op, and induction and placement of the LMA are uneventful. Ten minutes later, during surgical prep, the patient's vital signs show HR 115/min, BP 148/96 mmHg, RR 14/min, ETCO2 40 mmhg & SpO2 99%. The end-tidal desflurane value reads 8.5, and the only other medication administered at this point was cefazolin. What is the most likely cause for the patient's clinical condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Allergic reaction to perioperative antibiotic administered.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy has a medical history complicated by alpha thalassemia intermediate and previous abdominal surgery for intussusception as a toddler. Three days ago, he also had surgery for a congenital hernia repair at a rural hospital. Intraoperatively the case was complicated by hypotension and refractory brady arrhythmias. Which of the following is the mechanism leading to this child's intraoperative complications?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha thalassemia leading to hypotension and subsequent arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic hysterectomy. Induction was performed using 140 mg propofol and 100 mcg fentanyl with subsequent 70 mg rocuronium. After intubation, anesthesia was rapidly maintained with an inhaled anesthetic. Within the first minute of administering the inhaled anesthetic, the patient’s heart rate decreased from 70 beats per minute to 50 beats per minute, and the blood pressure decreased from 130/70 mmHg to 80\48 mmHg. Which of the following inhalation agents was most likely used to induce the above response?

A 65-year-old patient is taken for a liver transplant surgery for chronic liver failure. He is induced with a combination of etomidate and fentanyl and atracurium as a muscle relaxant. Which of the following would be the inhalational agent of choice for maintenance of anesthesia in this patient?
The cylinder size most used on anesthesia machines and for patient transport is
Potency of anaesthetic agent can be estimated by:

A 12-year-old boy is having a general anesthetic for open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of an elbow fracture. He was induced with rocuronium, propofol, and fentanyl and after intubation has been maintained on sevoflurane. Approximately 1 hour later the patient is tachycardic with a heart rate of 133 beats per minute, his end-tidal CO2 is 84 mm Hg, and his temperature is 39°C. What is the best initial approach to treating this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Switch to another anesthesia machine and administer Dantrolene intravenously.

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinue inhaled sevoflurane and cool the patient with topical ice.

options.label: C
options.text: Discontinue inhaled sevoflurane and administer Dantrolene intravenously.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer IV sodium bicarbonate and cool the patient with topical ice.

questions.correct_answer: C. Discontinue inhaled sevoflurane and administer Dantrolene intravenously.

questions.text: An 11-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis complains of being unable to see in the postanaesthetic care unit (PACU) after a posterior fusion in the prone position. This does not improve over the next 2 days. The most likely mechanism is thought to be:

An 8-year-old girl is undergoing resection of a posterior fossa tumour in the sitting position. A sudden decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide (CO2) associated with an audible change in the precordial Doppler tones most likely originates from:
The following sites allow accurate measures of core temperature except:

A 65-year-old male, heavy smoker, with COPD is having micro laryngeal surgery under general anaesthesia. He is intubated and ventilated. During the procedure, his saturation on pulse oximeter start to dip and he develops an expiratory wheeze, and it is getting difficult to ventilate. Which of the statements below is the most appropriate in the immediate management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase the ventilation pressures to improve oxygenation.

options.label: B
options.text: Salbutamol via tracheal tube or intravenously may be beneficial.

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous corticosteroids should be administered immediately.

options.label: D
options.text: The airway device may be changed to a laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.correct_answer: B. Salbutamol via tracheal tube or intravenously may be beneficial.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is to be taken for correction of congenital squint. His preoperative course had been uneventful, and all labs are normal. General anesthesia was planned for the surgery with a standard induction of propofol and fentanyl with atracurium as muscle relaxant. The patient was given sevoflurane for the maintenance of anesthesia. 10 mins into the surgery the child suddenly developed bradycardia and hypotension. The surgeon was immediately informed, and he released the pressure on extraocular muscles and child was given iv atropine stat and the heart rate came to normal. This was supposed to be a reflex response very typical of this surgery. What is the efferent neuron of the reflex arc?

A 34-year-old female is taken up for a laparoscopic removal of gall bladder. The patients past medical history is suggestive of bronchial asthma on regular treatment. Last exacerbation was 4 months back during the onset of winter season. Rest all her lab investigations are normal. The patient is taken for surgery and a cautious general anesthesia is given with ketamine as induction agent and vecuronium as long-acting muscle relaxant for the procedure. Adequate depth of anesthesia is maintained throughout the procedure and the course is uneventful. At the end of the procedure, the patient is extubated while still unconscious but has started to breath spontaneously a technique commonly referred to as “deep extubation”. "Deep extubation," i.e. endotracheal extubation from a deep plane of anesthesia, is theoretically thought to confer which of the following benefits?

A 44-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 1, and depression presents for elective inguinal hernia repair. The patient is taking lisinopril, metformin, and sertraline. Patient was induced with a standard dose of thiopentone and fentanyl along with atracurium as muscle relaxant. After successful intubation, the patient was maintained on inhalational halothane with mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide on controlled ventilation. Shortly after that the patient develops tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia. What is the best initial therapy for this patient?

A 17-year-old boy suffers a right distal humeral fracture after a football game. The anaesthesiologist performed a right axillary brachial plexus and musculocutaneous nerve blocks for postoperative analgesia after induction of general anesthesia. During emergence, the patient is acutely agitated and violently sits up while his arms were restrained. At the clinic follow up appointment, the patient is having trouble a loss of sensation in left hand, especially in his ring and little fingers. a loss of coordination in fingers. a tingling or burning sensation in his hand. What might have directly avoided this injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Administering dexmedetomidine 0.5 mcg/kg at 20 minutes prior to emergence

options.label: B
options.text: Performing the axillary brachial plexus block while the patient was awake

options.label: C
options.text: Better padding during the football game

options.label: D
options.text: Proper padding and positioning of the patient during surgery

questions.correct_answer: D. Proper padding and positioning of the patient during surgery

questions.text: "Shivering" is observed in the early part of postoperative period due to:
Local anaesthetics are available in various strengths and preparations:

options.label: A
options.text: Glucose is added to bupivacaine to make hypobaric solution.

options.label: B
options.text: The preservative methyl paraben is often added as a preservative.

options.label: C
options.text: The addition of bicarbonate reduces the amount of the unionized form of the local anaesthetic.

options.label: D
options.text: Lidocaine and amethocaine are mixed in equal parts to form a eutectic mixture of local anaesthetic cream.

questions.correct_answer: B. The preservative methyl paraben is often added as a preservative.

questions.text: Metabolism of local anaesthetics depends on chemical structure.

options.label: A
options.text: Amide local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized by plasma cholinesterase.

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolism of bupivacaine is independent of hepatic function.

options.label: C
options.text: Ester local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized in cerebrospinal fluid.

options.label: D
options.text: Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine.

questions.correct_answer: D. Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is requesting regional anesthesia during labour. The provider plans to perform a nerve block via the transvaginal approach. During the procedure, the patient develops arrhythmias and gets hypotensive. The patient is suffering from which of the complications of this specific procedure?

A 31-year old primigravida, pregnant for 38 weeks, was brought to the emergency department. The patient was having labor pains for the past four hours, and her membranes had ruptured three hours ago. The clinician performed a per-vaginal examination, which revealed that her cervix was fully dilated, and the head of the fetus was at station 0. Detailed history taking showed that the patient had no history of any chronic disease or co-morbidity. Her total leukocyte count, platelet count, and coagulation profile were within the normal range. She was prepared to deliver, and saddle block anesthesia was planned as a method for labor analgesia. The duration of labor was prolonged, and the effect of analgesia wore off earlier than anticipated. What measure can be taken while performing the said neuraxial block to ensure a prolonged duration of analgesia without the added risk of narcotizing the baby?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of a higher dose of anesthetic agent

options.label: B
options.text: Premedication with an intravenous opioid such as nalbuphine

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of a long-acting anesthetic agent such as bupivacaine

options.label: D
options.text: Changing the position of the patient to jack-knife after only one minute of sitting

questions.correct_answer: C. Administration of a long-acting anesthetic agent such as bupivacaine

questions.text: A 17-year-old female is suffering from large breast abscess. She has to be taken for incision and drainage. Due to unavailability of an anesthesiologist the surgeon decides to perform the procedure under local infiltration. After routine investigation and adequate preoperative fasting, the patient is taken up for surgery. The surgeon aspirates 15 ml of 2 % lignocaine for anesthesia and infiltrates the abscess all around the margins and the apex of the abscess as well. After waiting for 5 mins for the action of lignocaine to take effect he takes a stab knife and takes the incision. Immediately the patient winces in pain and becomes hypertensive and tachycardiac. Which ONE of the following statements best describes this local anaesthetic activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Action of lignocaine is increased in alkaline environment

options.label: B
options.text: Dependent on uncharged molecules crossing the cell membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Action of lignocaine is decreased in acidic environment

options.label: D
options.text: Deeper block with increasing action potential frequency

questions.correct_answer: C. Action of lignocaine is decreased in acidic environment

questions.text: A frail 75-year-old woman was brought to emergency with a Colle’s fracture of the left wrist. A junior orthopaedic trainee manipulated the wrist using intravenous regional anaesthesia (Bier’s block) with 30 mL of 0.25 % levobupivacaine. Shortly after the cuff was deflated, the patient had symptoms of confusion, seizure, and hypotension, without cardiorespiratory arrest. The most appropriate next step in the management would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Give an initial intravenous bolus injection of 20 % lipid emulsion 1.5 mL/kg over 1 min.

questions.text: Which property of local anesthetic denotes its duration of action?
All of the following are ester type of local anesthetic except:
Which of the following types of regional anesthesia is associated with the GREATEST serum concentration of lidocaine?
Which state of local anesthetic molecule is required for its action:
All of the following are proven benefits of epidural analgesia except:
Complications of supraclavicular brachial plexus block include all except:

A 25-year-old primipara has an accidental dural tap (ADT) with a 16-G tuohy needle while the anaesthetist was attempting labour epidural analgesia. A day after the ADT, the patient is complaining of severe positional frontal and occipital headache. Which of the following is not appropriate 1st line management?
Regarding lumbar puncture (LP) which of the following is true except?

options.label: A
options.text: LP can be performed at any lumbar level.

options.label: B
options.text: Incidence of post-dural puncture headache (pdph) is reduced using a 25g Pencil-point needle.

options.label: C
options.text: Contraindications include coagulopathy, patient refusal and local infection

options.label: D
options.text: Position of the patient is usually lateral.

questions.correct_answer: A. LP can be performed at any lumbar level.

questions.text: Complications of the interscalene approach to the brachial plexus include

Five hours after performing a left-sided interscalene brachial plexus injection of 40 mL of 0.25% bupivacaine (for analgesia), the provider is called to evaluate the patient for hypoxemia. Pulse oximetry is 86%, bilateral breath sounds are heard on chest auscultation, and chest x-ray demonstrates elevated left hemidiaphragm with no signs of pneumothorax. What is the likely diagnosis?

A healthy 29-year-old, 0 para female in gestation week 39, was planned for saddle block labor analgesia. The patient was taken to the operating room and prepared for the procedure. Her baseline vitals were recorded; the blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, the heart rate was 86/min, and the cardiac monitor showed a sinus rhythm electrocardiogram (ECG). The patient was maintained in an upright sitting position. The anesthesia was induced via a 25 G Quincke cutting needle inserted at L4-5 interspinous space. The subarachnoid space was at a depth of about six cms from the skin surface, and it was confirmed by the presence of clear cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dripping from the needle. The syringe containing the recommended standard dose of hyperbaric bupivacaine was attached to the spinal needle. The anesthesiologist overlooked the step to re-aspirate CSF into the needle and proceeded with the intrathecal administration of the drug. After completion of the injection, blood-tinged fluid dripped from the back of the spinal needle. Early in labor, the patient suddenly developed hypotension and was immediately administered with a suitable vasopressor. Soon after, the ECG showed an abnormal rhythm. The patient collapsed from the sudden arrhythmia. What is the complication that led to the systemic toxicity of the anesthetic drug?

A 24-year-old patient is taken for a ORIF of proximal radius and ulna fracture. There is no past medical history. all investigations are normal except that the patient is obese and has a thick neck. He is an anticipated difficult intubation. An axillary nerve block is performed. On incision, the patient complains of pain anterolateral forearm. Which nerve has been missed?

A 28-year-old patient G2P2 on a postpartum day 2 complaints about having an "intense headache." The patient reports that the headache started in the morning and describes it as an intense frontal headache, severity 7/10, improves with lying down, worsens with sitting up, accompanied by blurry vision, nausea, and tinnitus, and not relieved by acetaminophen. The patient had an uneventful vaginal delivery at 38 weeks of gestation with continuous epidural infusion for pain management. Which of the following actions is the most appropriate for this patient's current presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Rush the patient to the operating room for urgent craniotomy

options.label: B
options.text: Monitor the patient for respiratory depression

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure the patient that this type of headache is normal after delivery

questions.text: You have given an interscalene block for a patient undergoing shoulder surgery. However, about 30 min after the block, the patient finds that his voice is getting hoarse, and he is finding it difficult to speak. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
Intrathecal fentanyl is useful for postoperative analgesia after caesarean section, but which of the following is the most common side effect of using it?

A 31-year-old patient with a past history for asthma presented to the ER with difficulty in breathing and cough. Examination shows that he was using accessory muscles and lung auscultation showed extensive expiratory wheezing. Labs and chest x-ray were unremarkable. He did not respond to nebulizations, steroids, and IV magnesium treatment. He was put on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (BiPAP) by an ER physician which again he didn't tolerate. Eventually, he was intubated and to achieve better patient-ventilator synchrony he was deeply sedated. The second day in ICU his wheezing is much better. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Sedation vacation and spontaneous breathing trial

options.label: D
options.text: Do a spontaneous breathing trial on sedative medications

questions.correct_answer: B. Sedation vacation and spontaneous breathing trial

questions.text: A 17-year-old male is brought to the trauma bay following a gunshot wound to the left groin. The patient is noted to be obtunded, and his Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 7/15. EMS reports that the patient was found in a large pool of blood in an alleyway. The incident was not witnessed, and it is unclear how long the patient was down. The pressure is currently being held on the groin. Vitals include heart rate 127/min, blood pressure 82/40 mmHg, and respiratory rate 27/min. The patient is unable to provide any information. What is the immediate next best step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Left groin exploration and control of hemorrhage

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents for hip arthroscopy to address and treat his labral tears and associated hip pain. The best option for opioid therapy in this patient is:
The following may be measured by device shown in the image?

A 54-year-old patient is having retinal detachment surgery under general anaesthetic. During the surgery the patient became bradycardic with heart rate of 40 beats per minute and blood pressure of 75/40. What is the first thing would you do?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduce the inspired inhalation concentration of isoflurane.

options.label: D
options.text: Stop the surgeon operating and release the muscles of the globe.

questions.correct_answer: D. Stop the surgeon operating and release the muscles of the globe.

questions.text: Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) was an improvement on intermittent mandatory ventilation (IMV) because it

options.label: A
options.text: Can provide full ventilation support to an apnoeic patient.

options.label: B
options.text: Can utilize volume-preset or pressure-preset ventilation.

options.label: C
options.text: Allows the patient to breathe spontaneously

options.label: D
options.text: Reduces the likelihood of breath stacking and volutrauma.

questions.correct_answer: D. Reduces the likelihood of breath stacking and volutrauma.

questions.text: Not used for measuring cardiac output in an ICU patient is:

options.label: C
options.text: Thermodilution method in Pulmonary artery catheter

options.label: D
options.text: Continuous Cardiac output monitoring via pulmonary artery

questions.text: Highest fiO2 delivery by which oxygen delivery device?
questions.correct_answer: B. Face mask with reservoir bag

questions.text: Endotracheal \ tracheostomy suction in an ICU patient should be done for how many seconds?

A 68-year-old man collapses in the middle of a mall. A good Samaritan immediately rushes to help the victim. He assesses the responsiveness and pulse and immediately starts cardiopulmonary resuscitation and calls for help by dialling 911. During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) he performs external chest compression at the rate of 90/min with 2 inches of sternal depression. The most appropriate action is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Continue the original pattern of CPR

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the depth of sternal depression

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase the rate of compression.

questions.text: Select the TRUE statement regarding cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation by a health care provider in patients experiencing sudden cardiac arrest.

options.label: A
options.text: Always analyse rhythm before starting CPR

options.label: B
options.text: CPR should always be carried out for 2 minutes prior to defibrillation

options.label: C
options.text: Two minutes of chest compressions alone (no ventilation) should be carried out prior to first shock

options.label: D
options.text: If AED is available immediately then deliver one biphasic shock then five cycles of CPR

questions.correct_answer: D. If AED is available immediately then deliver one biphasic shock then five cycles of CPR

questions.text: Where should you attempt to perform a pulse check in an adult?
After delivering a shock, what is the next step in caring of a cardiac arrest victim?

you are a daycare provider and find a 3-year-old child who is unresponsive. She had laid down for a nap because she was not feeling well. When you checked on her, she was not breathing and appeared blue. You are by yourself. What is the first step in managing this case?
questions.correct_answer: D. Deliver two minutes of cpr.

questions.text: A 32-year-old was having dinner when suddenly he couldn’t breathe and started showing universal choking sign. A bystander immediately took notice and did something to help the patient which is shown in the image below. Which of the following maneuver is being shown?
How long should you check for breathing while performing CPR?

options.label: A
options.text: Do not check for breathing, continue chest compressions

questions.text: When you try to give an unresponsive adult a rescue breath and the chest does not appear to rise, what would you do next?

options.label: D
options.text: Repeat the head tilt/chin lift maneuver and attempt the breath again

questions.correct_answer: D. Repeat the head tilt/chin lift maneuver and attempt the breath again

questions.text: Arriving first to the scene, you find an unresponsive person with no pulse that has thrown up. You feel CPR is not something you are comfortable giving them. What would be the next best thing for you to do?

options.label: A
options.text: Wipe off the face or cover with a shirt

questions.text: When operating an AED, what are the correct steps to follow?

options.label: A
options.text: Power on the AED, attach electrode pads, shock the individual, and analyze the rhythm

options.label: B
options.text: Power on the AED, attach electode pads, analyze the rhythm, clear the individual, and deliver shock

options.label: C
options.text: Attach electrode pads, check pulse, shock individual, and analyze rhythm

options.label: D
options.text: Check pulse, attach electrode pads, analyze rhythm, shock patient

questions.correct_answer: B. Power on the AED, attach electode pads, analyze the rhythm, clear the individual, and deliver shock
